<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Information required with respect to equity compensation plan
information can be found in Item&nbsp;11 of this report.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In June 2004, the Company&#146;s Board of Directors authorized
up to $150&nbsp;million for purchases of common stock, replacing
the previous authorization. During fiscal 2006, the Company
repurchased 250,000&nbsp;shares of its outstanding common stock.
As of April&nbsp;24, 2006, approximately $107.4&nbsp;million of
the authorization remains available. Future repurchases of
common stock may be made in open market or private transactions
from time to time depending on prevailing market conditions, the
Company&#146;s available cash and the Company&#146;s
consideration of any loan agreement restrictions and its
corporate credit ratings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
There were no purchases of common stock of the Company made
during the three months ended February&nbsp;25, 2006, by
Pier&nbsp;1 Imports, Inc. or any &#147;affiliated
purchaser&#148; of Pier&nbsp;1 Imports, Inc. as defined in
Rule&nbsp;<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">10b-18(a)(3)</FONT>
under the Exchange Act of 1934.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company is not required to comply with financial covenants
under its new secured credit facility unless the availability
under such agreement is less than $32.5&nbsp;million. The
Company had no cash borrowings outstanding under its credit
facility, and the Company was in compliance with all material
debt covenants at fiscal 2006&nbsp;year-end. The Company was
granted a waiver by the lenders subsequent to year-end in
connection with the restatement of the Company&#146;s
consolidated statements of cash flows for fiscal 2005 and 2004.
During fiscal 2006, the Company paid cash dividends totaling
approximately $34.7&nbsp;million, or $0.40&nbsp;per share. In
March 2006, the Company declared a cash dividend of
$0.10&nbsp;per share payable on May&nbsp;17, 2006, to
shareholders of record on May&nbsp;3, 2006. The Company may
continue to pay cash dividends and repurchase its common stock
in fiscal 2007, but expects to retain most of its future
earnings for support and expansion of the Company&#146;s
business. The Company&#146;s dividend policy will depend upon
the earnings, financial condition and capital needs of the
Company and other factors deemed relevant by the Company&#146;s
Board of Directors. Dividend payments are not restricted by the
new secured credit facility unless the availability under the
credit facility is less than 30% of the Company&#146;s borrowing
base calculation. Such borrowing base calculation consists of a
percentage of eligible inventory and third party credit card
receivables and varies according to the levels of the underlying
collateral.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">15
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
<A name='111'></A>
</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Item 7. Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations." -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B>Item&nbsp;7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><U>Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
    Condition and Results of Operations.</U></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>MANAGEMENT OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Introduction</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Pier&nbsp;1 Imports, Inc. (together with its consolidated
subsidiaries, the &#147;Company&#148;) is one of North
America&#146;s largest specialty retailers of unique decorative
home furnishings, gifts and related items. The Company imports
merchandise directly from over 40&nbsp;countries, and sells a
wide variety of furniture collections, decorative accessories,
bed and bath products, housewares and other seasonal assortments
in its stores. During fiscal year 2006, the Company opened
86&nbsp;new stores and closed 40&nbsp;stores, increasing retail
square footage&nbsp;3.6% over the prior year. The Company
operates stores in the United States and Canada under the names
&#147;Pier&nbsp;1 Imports&#148; (&#147;Pier&nbsp;1&#148;), and
&#147;Pier&nbsp;1 Kids.&#148; Pier&nbsp;1 Kids stores sell
children&#146;s home furnishings and decorative accessories. In
the United Kingdom and Ireland, retail locations have operated
under the name &#147;The Pier.&#148; As of February&nbsp;25,
2006, the Company operated 1,304 stores in the United States,
Canada, Puerto&nbsp;Rico, the United Kingdom, Ireland and Mexico.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2006, the Company&#146;s
Board of Directors authorized management to sell its operations
of The Pier stores and concessions located in the United Kingdom
and Ireland. The Company met the criteria of Statement of
Financial Accounting Standards, No.&nbsp;144, &#147;Accounting
for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148; that
allowed it to classify The Pier as held for sale and present its
results of operations as discontinued at year-end, with prior
periods reclassified accordingly. On March&nbsp;20, 2006, the
Company sold The Pier to Palli Limited for approximately
$15.0&nbsp;million. Palli Limited is a wholly owned subsidiary
of Lagerinn ehf, an Iceland corporation owned by Jakup a
Dul&nbsp;Jacobsen. According to Mr.&nbsp;Jacobsen&#146;s
Schedule&nbsp;13D filing, collectively Lagerinn and
Mr.&nbsp;Jacobsen beneficially owned approximately 9.9% of the
Company&#146;s common stock on March&nbsp;20, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The following discussion and analysis of financial condition,
results of operations, liquidity and capital resources relates
to continuing operations, unless otherwise stated, and should be
read in conjunction with the accompanying audited Consolidated
Financial Statements and notes thereto which can be found in
Item&nbsp;8 of this report.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Overview of Business</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net sales from continuing operations decreased 2.7% to
$1,776.7&nbsp;million in fiscal 2006 compared to
$1,825.3&nbsp;million in fiscal 2005, and comparable store sales
declined 7.1%. The Company&#146;s net loss from continuing
operations was $27.5&nbsp;million during fiscal 2006, or
$0.32&nbsp;per share compared with diluted earnings per share of
$0.71 for the prior fiscal year. The Company ended the year with
$246.1&nbsp;million in cash and cash equivalents. Throughout the
year, the Company continued to pay cash dividends to
shareholders.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">17

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s key financial and operational metrics used by
management to evaluate the performance of the business include
the following (trends for these metrics are explained in the
comparative sections of this section):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt; margin-top: 12pt; ">

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    <B>Continuing operations:</B></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Stores included in the comparable store sales calculation are
those stores that were opened prior to the beginning of the
preceding fiscal year and are still open. Also included are
stores that were relocated during the year within a specified
distance serving the same market, where there is not a
significant change in store size and where there is not a
significant overlap or gap in timing between the opening of the
new store and the closing of the existing store. Stores that are
expanded or renovated are excluded from the comparable store
sales calculation during the period they are closed for such
remodeling. When these stores re-open for business, they are
included in the comparable store sales calculation in the first
full month after the re-opening if there is no significant
change in store size. If there is a significant change in store
size, the store continues to be excluded from the calculation
until it meets the Company&#146;s established definition of a
comparable store. Sales over the Internet (which includes direct
sales from catalog) are also included.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Throughout fiscal 2006, the Company continued to struggle with
declining sales performance. Challenged with how to increase
customer traffic and differentiate itself from the growing
competition, the Company implemented several key initiatives. To
regain its position as a unique specialty retailer, the Company
is focusing on merchandising and marketing strategies as well as
prudent management of the business through cost reductions and
other restructuring plans throughout the organization.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Through market research and customer feedback, the Company
determined that the stores needed an updated look; complete with
new merchandise lines and a redesigned store format. Market
research showed that customers are looking for a &#147;less is
more&#148; style of home furnishings, with more efficient and
convenient shopping options. As a result, the Company has
introduced a new line of merchandise with more contemporary
designs, updated color palettes and a modern look. In addition
to shelf displays, customers entering Pier&nbsp;1 stores will
now find merchandise arrangements designed to fit into
particular areas of the home such as the living room, dining
room, bedroom or patio. The new merchandise is displayed in a
manner that allows the customers to imagine what it would look
like in their own homes, as well as showing them how to
incorporate different accessories into their living areas. This
simplified, less cluttered visual presentation was partially
achieved by reducing the total number of SKUs at the stores. In
addition, the Company recently implemented a new rapid
replenishment process in its stores where more merchandise is
now held at the distribution centers rather than in stores and
is restocked as merchandise sells. This new process has removed
at least a week from the restocking time in stores and helped to
maintain the clean, contemporary look of the stores. Also,
during the fourth quarter the Company doubled
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">18

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
its number of outlet stores to help with the flow of merchandise
and to keep the stores from appearing cluttered as the Company
transitions merchandise throughout the year.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In addition to the new merchandise initiatives, the Company has
implemented new marketing strategies including new television
advertisements, catalog mailings, magazine advertisements, and
direct mail and Internet marketing. The Company has returned to
television advertising after discontinuing this form of
advertising in the latter half of fiscal 2005 and has
discontinued the use of newspaper inserts for now.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company began test marketing its catalog through limited
mailings late in fiscal 2005 and again in early fiscal 2006 and
decided to expand the mailings of catalogs with two nation-wide
distributions during the fall and holiday season of fiscal 2006.
Customer response was positive and the Company has decided to
continue to expand this form of marketing and discontinue the
use of newspaper inserts. The catalog offers an opportunity to
show product to its best advantage, to suggest its use in home
settings and to demonstrate the value proposition. In March
2006, the Company circulated ten million copies of the spring
catalog. In April, the Company circulated a late spring edition
of the catalog and will follow it with a summer catalog in May.
In all, the Company plans to distribute nine direct mail
catalogs throughout fiscal&nbsp;2007. The Company&#146;s
management feels that the catalogs will play an increasingly
important role in the overall marketing plan as well as provide
the Company with future business opportunities. Almost all items
available through catalogs and Internet shopping are also
available in stores.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In an effort to reduce costs and focus on the core business, the
Company has made several key changes throughout the year, as
follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
    The Company&#146;s management reviewed and identified key areas
    of the Company where cost reduction and cost restructuring would
    be beneficial. As a result, the Company made the decision to
    integrate Pier&nbsp;1 Kids operations within Pier&nbsp;1 more
    fully by moving its administrative functions to
    Pier&nbsp;1&#146;s corporate headquarters and utilizing the
    Savannah distribution center for distribution to Pier&nbsp;1
    Kids stores. In addition, the Company centralized the field
    administration function, reduced the number of regions and
    districts and eliminated associated support functions, and
    reduced the staffing of the real estate function. Also, overall
    information technology spending was reduced where practical and
    a number of corporate administrative positions were eliminated.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6.0pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
    During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2006, the Company&#146;s
    management began a comprehensive evaluation of its real estate
    portfolio of Pier&nbsp;1 and Pier&nbsp;1 Kids stores. As a
    result of this evaluation, the Company&#146;s management decided
    to close 38&nbsp;stores in fiscal 2006, compared to the original
    plan to close&nbsp;27, and expects to close&nbsp;35 in fiscal
    2007. The increase in closures is an effort to focus on the
    stores in the higher performing markets and not continue to
    invest resources in marginal or underperforming stores.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6.0pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
    Lastly, management decided to sell The Pier stores located in
    the United Kingdom and Ireland. Managing operations in distant
    locations was a management distraction, and the Company has
    chosen to focus on operations in North America. Additionally,
    the stores opened in North America have historically provided a
    higher return on investment than those opened in the United
    Kingdom, and the Company determined that it would be a better
    use of its capital to focus its expansion efforts in North
    America.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Despite a difficult year, the Company&#146;s management
continues to focus on managing inventory levels and controlling
operating expenses prudently. The Company plans to continue to
monitor customer preferences as they shift each season, and to
adjust the Company&#146;s marketing and merchandising strategies
to meet the needs of its customers. Customers have responded
favorably to the new merchandising and marketing strategies and
management believes that the steps it is taking will help to
increase customer traffic and sales.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">19

Net sales consisted almost entirely of sales to retail
customers, net of discounts and returns, but also included
delivery service revenues and wholesale sales and royalties
received from franchise stores and Sears Roebuck
de&nbsp;Mexico,&nbsp;S.A. de C.V. Sales by retail concept during

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other sales consisted of wholesale sales and royalties received
    from franchise stores and from Sears&nbsp;de Mexico S.A., and
    Pier&nbsp;1 Kids&#146; contract sales. As of August 2003,
    Pier&nbsp;1 Kids discontinued sales of merchandise under
    wholesale contracts.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net sales during fiscal 2006 were $1,776.7&nbsp;million, a
decrease of $48.6&nbsp;million, or 2.7%, from
$1,825.3&nbsp;million for the prior fiscal year. The decrease in
sales for the fiscal year was comprised of the following
components (in thousands):
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt; margin-top: 6pt; ">

<TR style="font-size: 1pt;">
    <TD width="85%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B>2006</B></TD><TD></TD>

    Comparable stores</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#cceeff">
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left: 10px; text-indent: -10px">
    Net decrease in sales</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">$</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>(48,642</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Comparable store sales for fiscal 2006 decreased 7.1% primarily
as a result of decreased store traffic and increased competition
from other retailers. Throughout the year, the Company has
struggled to maintain and increase customer traffic, which the
Company believes was the result of its inability to
differentiate its merchandise from competitors through its
marketing campaign. In an effort to encourage customers to
return to the stores, the Company distributed its first two
nation-wide catalogs. The first catalog was mailed in the fall
and the second in the holiday season. The Company&#146;s net
sales from Canada were subject to fluctuations in currency
conversion rates. These fluctuations had an immaterial favorable
impact on both total net sales and comparable store sales
calculations in fiscal 2006 compared to fiscal 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company opened&nbsp;65 and closed 32&nbsp;North American
Pier&nbsp;1 stores during fiscal 2006, bringing the Pier&nbsp;1
store count to 1,183 at year end, compared to 1,150 last year.
The Company also opened four and closed six Pier&nbsp;1 Kids
stores and opened one store and one &#147;store within a
store&#148; in Mexico. Including all worldwide locations the
Company&#146;s store count for continuing operations totaled
1,259 at the end of fiscal&nbsp;2006, which represents an
increase of 3.2% in total retail square footage compared to the
end of last fiscal year. During fiscal 2007, the Company expects
to open 40 new Pier&nbsp;1 stores and close approximately
30&nbsp;stores, close five Pier&nbsp;1 Kids stores and open five
stores in Mexico and two in Puerto Rico. A summary
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">20

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>15</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    Closings</DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"><FONT style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    International stores were located in Puerto Rico and Mexico.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3.0pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(2)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Discontinued operations relate to The Pier (fiscal 2006 openings
    included 12 &#147;store within a store&#148; formats.)</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s proprietary credit card generated net sales
of $422.5&nbsp;million, a decrease of $38.7&nbsp;million or 8.4%
from last year&#146;s proprietary credit card sales of
$461.2&nbsp;million. Sales on the proprietary credit card
totaled 25.7% of United States store sales compared to 27.1%
last year. Average ticket on the Company&#146;s proprietary
credit card increased to $163 during fiscal&nbsp;2006 from $159
during fiscal 2005. At the end of the second quarter of fiscal
2006, in an effort to stimulate sales on the proprietary credit
card, the Company began offering a
<FONT style="white-space: nowrap">12-month,</FONT> no interest
promotion on larger purchases as well as supporting special
incentives for store associates to encourage customers to open
new credit card accounts. While the proprietary credit card
generates modest income, it primarily serves as a tool for
marketing and communication to the Company&#146;s most loyal
customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Gross Profit</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Gross profit after related buying and store occupancy costs,
expressed as a percentage of sales, was 33.9% in
fiscal&nbsp;2006 compared to 38.5% a year ago. Merchandise
margins, as a percentage of sales, declined from 53.1% in fiscal
2005 to 50.2% in fiscal&nbsp;2006, a decrease of 290&nbsp;basis
points. The decline in merchandise margin rates resulted
primarily from the Company&#146;s continued use of promotional
discounts and clearance markdowns in an effort to stimulate
sales as well as make way for new and unique merchandise lines.
Store occupancy costs during fiscal 2006 were
$290.4&nbsp;million or 16.3% of sales, an increase of
$24.1&nbsp;million and 170&nbsp;basis points over store
occupancy costs of $266.3&nbsp;million or 14.6% of sales during
fiscal 2005. This increase was primarily due to an inability to
leverage relatively fixed rental costs over a lower sales base.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Operating Expenses, Depreciation and Income Taxes</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Selling, general and administrative expenses, including
marketing, comprised 33.1% of sales in fiscal 2006, an increase
of 300&nbsp;basis points over last year&#146;s 30.1% of sales.
In total dollars, selling, general and administrative expenses
increased $38.6&nbsp;million in fiscal 2006 over fiscal 2005,
with $34.1&nbsp;million of the increase attributable to expenses
that normally vary with sales and number of new stores, such as
marketing, store payroll, supplies, and equipment rental. These
variable expenses increased 250&nbsp;basis points as a
percentage of sales for fiscal 2006 compared to fiscal 2005.
Despite the negative comparable store sales for the year, the
Company intentionally did not decrease store payroll hours in an
effort to maintain minimum staffing levels and continue to
provide good customer service. In addition, the Company was
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">21

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
unable to leverage certain fixed portions of store payroll costs
over the lower sales base. In an effort to increase customer
traffic to its stores, marketing expenditures during fiscal 2006
were planned to increase over fiscal 2005 and were up
$16.0&nbsp;million to 5.8% of sales, an increase over fiscal
2005 of 105&nbsp;basis points expressed as a percentage of
sales. The Company had discontinued its television advertising
campaign last year when viewed by management as ineffective at
increasing customer traffic and driving sales. From October 2004
through February 2005, the Company had no television
advertising. During fiscal 2006, the Company re-launched a
national television advertising campaign and distributed two
nation-wide catalogs while discontinuing its newspaper insert
programs. The Company continually reassesses its advertising
campaign&#146;s effectiveness and revises its plans based upon
customer research and feedback. Store supplies and equipment
rental increased $2.6&nbsp;million and 20&nbsp;basis points as a
percentage of sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Relatively fixed selling, general and administrative expenses
increased $4.6&nbsp;million in fiscal 2006, or 50&nbsp;basis
points as a percentage of sales over last year. Other occupancy
expenses (excluding store and distribution center occupancy
expenses) increased $4.9&nbsp;million or 30&nbsp;basis points,
primarily as a result of impairment charges of $5.8&nbsp;million
recognized on long-lived store-level assets, which related
largely to the approximate 35 stores expected to close in fiscal
2007, compared to impairment charges in fiscal 2005 of
$0.4&nbsp;million. In addition, the Company had a
$1.0&nbsp;million write-off of the remaining balance of fixed
assets and intangibles associated with early store closures in
the current fiscal year. These non-cash charges were partially
offset by a $2.3&nbsp;million savings in home office rental
expense as the corporate headquarters were rented for a portion
of fiscal 2005 but were owned for all of fiscal 2006. Lease
accounting adjustments decreased $6.6&nbsp;million or
40&nbsp;basis points as a percentage of sales from the prior
year, primarily as a result of a cumulative correction of
$6.3&nbsp;million recognized in the prior year related to
pre-opening store rental expense for leases entered into in
years prior to fiscal 2005. The Company&#146;s lease termination
expense increased $1.8&nbsp;million or 10&nbsp;basis points as a
percentage of sales, primarily as a result of closing stores
this year with longer remaining lease terms than those of the
stores closed in the prior year. Typically, the Company closes
stores upon lease expiration; however, due to the Company&#146;s
thorough re-evaluation of individual store performance, more
stores were closed prior to the lease expiration in an effort to
improve the Company&#146;s overall real estate portfolio. Net
proprietary credit card income increased $4.0&nbsp;million to
$7.2&nbsp;million, representing a 20&nbsp;basis point decrease
in relatively fixed selling, general and administrative expenses
as a percentage of sales. This increase in income was primarily
the result of increased finance charge income, a decrease in
processing charges and a decrease in bad debt expense. The
increase in finance charge income was primarily a result of a
modest increase in late payment fees and a reduction of the
number of days in the grace period before interest charges are
imposed. Non-store payroll increased $8.9&nbsp;million or
60&nbsp;basis points as a percentage of sales for the year
primarily as a result of a $4.6&nbsp;million increase in
officers&#146; retirement as well as planned payroll increases
related to annual merit increases and long-term incentives. An
additional $0.7&nbsp;million of severance costs related to field
and home-office restructurings also contributed to the increase
in non-store payroll. All other relatively fixed selling,
general and administrative expenses decreased $0.4&nbsp;million
and increased 10&nbsp;basis points as a percentage of sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Depreciation and amortization for fiscal 2006 was
$56.2&nbsp;million, representing an increase of approximately
$0.5&nbsp;million over last year&#146;s depreciation and
amortization expense of $55.8&nbsp;million. This increase was
primarily the result of an increase in net new store openings,
depreciation on software applications that were launched
subsequent to the end of fiscal 2005 and a full year of
depreciation on the Company&#146;s corporate headquarters in the
current year versus a partial year last year. These increases
were partially offset by a slight reduction in depreciation
expense for certain assets that were fully depreciated during
the year.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In fiscal 2006, the Company had an operating loss of
$42.8&nbsp;million, a decline of $141.1&nbsp;million from the
prior years&#146; operating income of $98.2&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s effective tax rate was 34.5% of pretax income
(loss) from continuing operations, compared to 36.7% in fiscal
2005 and 29.9% of pretax loss from discontinued operations. The
decrease in the Company&#146;s effective tax rate from
continuing operations was primarily the result of state tax
liabilities.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">22

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Net Loss</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net loss from continuing operations in fiscal 2006 was
$27.5&nbsp;million or $0.32&nbsp;per share, a decrease of
$90.2&nbsp;million as compared to fiscal 2005&#146;s net income
from continuing operations of $62.8&nbsp;million, or
$0.71&nbsp;per share on a diluted basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net losses from discontinued operations were $12.3&nbsp;million
or $0.14&nbsp;per share in fiscal 2006 and $2.3&nbsp;million or
$0.03&nbsp;per share in fiscal 2005. The pre-tax loss of
$17.6&nbsp;million was the result of The Pier&#146;s loss from
operations of $10.1&nbsp;million and a $7.4&nbsp;million
impairment charge to write the assets down to fair value less
reasonable costs to sell. <I>See Note&nbsp;3 of the Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information
regarding discontinued operations.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total net loss in fiscal 2006 was $39.8&nbsp;million, or
$0.46&nbsp;per share, a decrease in earnings of
$100.3&nbsp;million as compared to fiscal 2005&#146;s net income
of $60.5&nbsp;million, or $0.68&nbsp;per share on a diluted
basis.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD>

</TABLE>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net sales consisted almost entirely of sales to retail
customers, net of discounts and returns, but also included
delivery service revenues and wholesale sales and royalties
received from franchise stores and Sears Roebuck de&nbsp;Mexico,
S.A.&nbsp;de C.V. Sales by retail concept during fiscal years
2005, 2004 and 2003 were as follows (in thousands):

<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1pt solid #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Other sales consisted of wholesale sales and royalties received
    from franchise stores and from Sears de Mexico S.A., and
    Pier&nbsp;1 Kids&#146; contract sales. Also included in amounts
    from fiscal 2003 were Pier&nbsp;1 Kids&#146; dealer sales, which
    were discontinued in fiscal 2003. As of August 2003, Pier&nbsp;1
    Kids discontinued sales of merchandise under wholesale contracts.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During fiscal 2005, the Company recorded net sales of
$1,825.3&nbsp;million, an increase of $19.3&nbsp;million or
1.1%, over net sales of $1,806.1&nbsp;million for fiscal year
2004. Incremental sales growth for fiscal 2005 was comprised of
the following components (in thousands):
</DIV>

    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 3pt double #000000;">&nbsp;</TD>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Comparable store sales for fiscal 2005 decreased 6.1%. The
Company believed that comparable store sales suffered as a
result of a challenging retail environment with weakened
discretionary spending among its target consumer group and
increased competition from discount retailers. In addition to
these external factors, the Company recognized the weak sales
performance in fiscal 2005 was also attributable to an
ineffective marketing campaign, merchandise assortment that
lacked uniqueness and value, and stores that had become
cluttered and difficult to shop. As a result of the above
factors, the Company experienced
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">23

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
decreased customer traffic and conversion rates (transactions
divided by traffic counts.) Management began to address these
issues mid-way through fiscal 2005 by conducting a complete
reassessment of the business and began to initiate strategic
initiatives to focus on marketing, merchandising and store
operations. The Company&#146;s net sales from Canada were
subject to fluctuations in currency conversion rates. These
fluctuations had an immaterial favorable impact on both total
net sales and comparable store sales calculations during fiscal
2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total net sales growth benefited from new store openings during
fiscal 2005. The Company opened 104 and closed or relocated
37&nbsp;North American Pier&nbsp;1 stores during fiscal 2005,
bringing the Pier&nbsp;1 store count to 1,150 at year-end
compared to 1,083 for fiscal 2004. The Company also
opened&nbsp;10 and closed five Pier&nbsp;1 Kids stores and
opened four locations with a &#147;store within a store&#148;
format in Sears Roebuck&nbsp;de Mexico S.A. de C.V. Including
all worldwide locations, the Company&#146;s store count for
continuing operations totaled 1,226 at the end of fiscal 2005,
which represented an increase of approximately 7.5% in total
retail square footage compared to the end of fiscal 2004. A
summary reconciliation of the Company&#146;s stores open at the
beginning of fiscal 2005, 2004 and 2003 to the number open at
the end of each period follows (openings and closings include
relocated stores):
</DIV>

<CENTER>

</CENTER>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 3.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<DIV style="width: 18%; border-top: 1.0pt solid black; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    International stores were located in Puerto Rico and Mexico.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3.0pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(2)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    Discontinued operations relate to The Pier.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s proprietary credit card generated net sales
of $461.2&nbsp;million for fiscal 2005, an increase of
$24.4&nbsp;million or 5.6% over fiscal 2004 proprietary credit
card sales of $436.8&nbsp;million. Sales on the proprietary
credit card were 27.1% for fiscal 2005 of United States store
sales compared to 25.9% for fiscal 2004. Average ticket on the
Company&#146;s proprietary credit card increased slightly to
$159 during fiscal 2005 from $158 during fiscal 2004. The
Company continued to try to increase total sales on its
proprietary credit card by developing customer loyalty through
marketing promotions targeted to cardholders, including deferred
payment options on larger purchases. Although the proprietary
credit card generated modest income, it primarily served as a
tool for marketing and communication to the Company&#146;s most
loyal customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Gross Profit</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Gross profit after related buying and store occupancy costs,
expressed as a percentage of sales, was 38.5% during fiscal
2005, a decrease of 360&nbsp;basis points compared to 42.1% in
fiscal 2004. Merchandise margins as a percentage of sales
declined 220&nbsp;basis points from 55.3% in fiscal 2004 to
53.1% in fiscal 2005. Decreased merchandise margins were
primarily the result of additional promotional discounts offered
to customers in an attempt to stimulate sales. The Company also
offered increased promotional discounts to reduce inventory
levels in connection with planned efforts to reduce overall SKU
counts and eliminate merchandise items that had been in the
sales mix longer than a year. Store occupancy costs during fiscal
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">24
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
2005 increased 150&nbsp;basis points to 14.6% of sales over
13.1% in fiscal 2004, primarily as a result of relatively fixed
rental costs on a lower sales base and from an increase in the
percentage of sales derived from newer and slightly larger
stores for which occupancy costs as a percentage of sales tend
to be higher until the stores reach maturity.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Operating Expenses, Depreciation and Income Taxes</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
As a percentage of sales, selling, general and administrative
expenses, including marketing, increased 100&nbsp;basis points
to 30.1% during fiscal 2005 over 29.1% of sales during fiscal
2004. In total dollars, selling, general and administrative
expenses increased $23.6&nbsp;million in fiscal 2005 over fiscal
2004. During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2005, the Company
revised its accounting practices for operating leases and
leasehold improvements to reflect guidance expressed by the
Office of the Chief Accountant of the Securities and Exchange
Commission to the American Institute of Certified Public
Accountants on February&nbsp;7, 2005. As a result, the Company
recorded a pre-tax charge of $7.5&nbsp;million (&#147;lease
accounting charge&#148;) to selling, general and administrative
expenses for rent expense attributable to time periods prior to
the opening of certain stores. Under this revision, these
periods were deemed to constitute a free rent period that was
considered in the straight-line rent expense calculation.
Related rent should be charged to the income statement during
the free rent period. This lease accounting charge included
$1.2&nbsp;million related to leases entered into in fiscal 2005
and a cumulative charge of $6.3&nbsp;million for leases entered
into in years prior to fiscal 2005, which was not material to
the consolidated financial statements for any previously
reported fiscal year. <I>See Note&nbsp;1 of the Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information
regarding the Company&#146;s lease accounting policies.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Expenses that normally increase proportionately with sales and
number of stores, such as marketing, store payroll, supplies and
equipment rental, increased $17.6&nbsp;million and 80&nbsp;basis
points during fiscal 2005 as a percentage of sales over fiscal
2004. Store payroll including bonus increased $17.1&nbsp;million
and 80&nbsp;basis points as a percentage of sales as comparable
store sales were insufficient to leverage store payroll costs
arising from the need to maintain sufficient staffing levels to
continue to provide an appropriate level of customer service,
while transitioning inventories and changing store visual
presentations. The Company&#146;s decision to discontinue
television advertising and terminate its relationship with its
previous agency reduced marketing expenses as a percentage of
sales for the latter half of fiscal 2005, almost entirely
offsetting higher expense as a percentage of sales through the
second quarter of fiscal 2005. Compared to fiscal 2004,
marketing expenses during fiscal 2005 decreased
$0.3&nbsp;million and less than 10&nbsp;basis points as a
percentage of sales and represented 4.8% of sales for fiscal
2005 compared to 4.9% of sales for fiscal 2004. Other variable
expenses, including supplies and equipment rental, increased
$0.8&nbsp;million and were flat as a percentage of sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Relatively fixed selling, general and administrative expenses
during fiscal 2005 increased $6.0&nbsp;million, or 25&nbsp;basis
points as a percentage of sales over fiscal 2004. The
$6.3&nbsp;million cumulative impact of the lease accounting
charge discussed above increased these expenses by 35&nbsp;basis
points as a percentage of sales. The fiscal 2005 effect of the
lease accounting charge was $1.2&nbsp;million, increasing
relatively fixed selling, general and administrative expenses by
10&nbsp;basis points as a percentage of sales. Home office
payroll increased $4.6&nbsp;million or 20&nbsp;basis points as a
percentage of sales, primarily as a result of annual merit
increases and increases in the Company&#146;s expense related to
retirement plans for officers and other employees. Partially
offsetting these increases was a decrease of $3.6&nbsp;million
or 20&nbsp;basis points in settlements and bad debts primarily
as a result of a non-recurring settlement in fiscal 2004 of a
class action lawsuit regarding compensation matters for which
the Company recorded a $2.6&nbsp;million charge. All other
relatively fixed selling, general and administrative expenses
decreased $2.5&nbsp;million or approximately 20&nbsp;basis
points as a percentage of sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Depreciation and amortization for fiscal 2005 was
$55.8&nbsp;million, representing an increase of
$6.9&nbsp;million over fiscal 2004 depreciation and amortization
expense of $48.9&nbsp;million. This increase was primarily the
result of net new store openings, depreciation on software
applications that were launched subsequent to the end of fiscal
2004, and depreciation on the new corporate headquarters that
began in
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">25

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
August 2004. These increases were partially offset by a
reduction in depreciation expense for certain assets that were
fully depreciated during fiscal 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In fiscal 2005, operating income declined to $98.2&nbsp;million
or 5.4% of sales from $186.0&nbsp;million or 10.3% of sales in
fiscal 2004, a decrease of 47.2% or $87.7&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s effective tax rate for fiscal 2005 was 36.7%
of income from continuing operations, a decrease from the fiscal
2004 effective tax rate of 37.1%.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>Net Income</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net income from continuing operations in fiscal 2005 was
$62.8&nbsp;million or $0.71&nbsp;per share on a diluted basis, a
decrease of $54.9&nbsp;million as compared to fiscal 2004&#146;s
net income from continuing operations of $117.7&nbsp;million, or
$1.29&nbsp;per share on a diluted basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Net loss from discontinued operations was $2.3&nbsp;million or
$0.03&nbsp;per share, a decrease of $2.6&nbsp;million as
compared to fiscal 2004&#146;s net income from discontinued
operations of $0.3&nbsp;million or $0.00&nbsp;per share on a
diluted basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Total net income in fiscal 2005 was $60.5&nbsp;million, or
$0.68&nbsp;per share on a diluted basis, a decrease of
$57.5&nbsp;million or 48.8% as compared to fiscal 2004&#146;s
net income of $118.0&nbsp;million, or $1.29&nbsp;per share on a
diluted basis. Net income decreased to 3.3% of sales in fiscal
2005 from 6.5% of sales in fiscal 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">
<B>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For the purposes of liquidity and capital resource discussions,
the Company&#146;s discontinued operations will be included in
financial results. The Company&#146;s cash and cash equivalents
including those from discontinued operations totaled
$253.2&nbsp;million at the end of fiscal 2006, an increase of
$64.1&nbsp;million over the fiscal 2005&nbsp;year-end balance of
$189.1&nbsp;million. Operating activities used
$64.3&nbsp;million of cash primarily due to the exchange of
proprietary credit card receivables for retained interests in
securitized receivables which are non-monetary transactions in
the operating section of the consolidated statements of cash
flows. This exchange resulted in a decrease in cash provided by
operating activities of $74.6&nbsp;million. Income tax
receivable increased to $18.0&nbsp;million as a result of
recording a federal income tax benefit related to the
Company&#146;s net loss for the year and federal refund claims
previously made. In addition, the Company&#146;s income tax
payable (primarily related to state taxes and foreign taxes)
decreased, using $7.0&nbsp;million during the year. Write-downs
of assets held for sale related to the sale of The Pier resulted
in a non-cash charge of $7.4&nbsp;million. Losses on impairment
of fixed assets, also non-cash charges, were $6.0&nbsp;million,
primarily attributable to the decision made by management to
accelerate the closing of certain stores with weaker sales.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During fiscal 2006, investing activities by the Company provided
a net $10.4&nbsp;million. Capital expenditures were
$51.0&nbsp;million and consisted primarily of $31.5&nbsp;million
for fixtures and leasehold improvements related to new and
existing stores for Pier&nbsp;1, The Pier, and Pier&nbsp;1 Kids,
$15.8&nbsp;million for information systems enhancements, and
$3.5&nbsp;million in expenditures for the Company&#146;s
distribution centers and infrastructure. The Company received
$1.4&nbsp;million from the disposition of properties, primarily
from the sale of one Company-owned store. Fiscal 2007 capital
expenditures are projected to be approximately $40&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
A contribution of $3.5&nbsp;million was made during fiscal 2006
to the consolidated trust that was established for the purpose
of setting aside funds to be used to settle pension obligations
upon the retirement or death of certain of the Company&#146;s
executive officers. The assets held by the trust are classified
as restricted investments. The Company sold $3.2&nbsp;million of
these restricted investments to settle pension obligations
during fiscal 2006. At year end, the trust had a balance of
$22.4&nbsp;million that may be used to pay future benefit
payments. Future contributions to the trust may be made in the
form of cash or other assets such as Company-owned life
insurance policies. <I>See Note&nbsp;11 of the Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information
regarding the restricted assets and pension obligations.</I>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">26

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During fiscal 2006, the Company&#146;s collection of principal
on beneficial interests in securitized receivables was
$60.2&nbsp;million. The Company&#146;s beneficial interest in
securitized receivables increased $14.3&nbsp;million to
$50.0&nbsp;million from $35.7&nbsp;million at the end of fiscal
2005. This increase resulted primarily from an increase in the
total proprietary credit card receivables portfolio of
$12.9&nbsp;million from $134.3&nbsp;million at fiscal
2005&nbsp;year-end to $147.3&nbsp;million at February&nbsp;25,
2006. In addition to the increase in receivables was a
$1.4&nbsp;million increase in cash held at the Master Trust at
year-end over last year. The Company continued to have
$100&nbsp;million of these beneficial interests held by outside
parties, and all proprietary credit card receivables were
securitized throughout fiscal 2006 and fiscal 2005. In prior
years, the Company had classified the net change in its
beneficial interest in the securitized receivables in the
investing section of the consolidated statements of cash flows.
In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2006, the Company concluded that
it had not appropriately reflected the exchange of its
proprietary credit card receivables for its retained interest in
the securitized receivables as a non-monetary transaction. As a
result, both cash provided by operating activities and cash used
in investing activities were overstated in the consolidated
statements of cash flows in each of the two years ended
February&nbsp;26, 2005. Accordingly, the Company has restated
the fiscal 2005 and fiscal 2004 consolidated statements of cash
flows. <I>See Note&nbsp;4 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements for additional information regarding the beneficial
interest in securitized receivables and Note&nbsp;2 for
discussion of the restatement of the consolidated statements of
cash flows.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Fiscal 2006 financing activities provided a net
$118.0&nbsp;million of the Company&#146;s cash. In February
2006, the Company issued $165.0&nbsp;million of
6.375%&nbsp;convertible senior notes due 2036 (the
&#147;Notes&#148;) in a private placement, and intends to
register the Notes with the Securities and Exchange Commission
by June 2006. The Company issued the Notes in order to maintain
flexibility and provide additional liquidity and plans to
utilize the proceeds for general corporate purposes. The Notes
bear interest at a rate of 6.375%&nbsp;per year until
February&nbsp;15, 2011 and at a rate of 6.125%&nbsp;per year
thereafter. Interest is payable semiannually in arrears on
February 15 and August 15 of each year, commencing
August&nbsp;15, 2006. The Notes are convertible into cash and,
if applicable, shares of the Company&#146;s common stock based
on an initial conversion rate, subject to adjustments, of
65.8328&nbsp;shares per $1,000 principal amount of Notes (which
represents an initial conversion price of approximately
$15.19&nbsp;per share representing a 40% conversion premium).
Holders of the Notes may convert their Notes only under the
following circumstances: (1)&nbsp;during any fiscal quarter (and
only during such fiscal quarter) commencing after May&nbsp;27,
2006, if the last reported sale price of the Company&#146;s
common stock is greater than or equal to 130% of the conversion
price per share of common stock for at least 20 trading days in
the period of 30 consecutive trading days ending on the last
trading day of the preceding fiscal quarter; (2)&nbsp;if the
Company has called the Notes for redemption; or (3)&nbsp;upon
the occurrence of specified corporate transactions. In general,
upon conversion of a Note, a holder will receive cash equal to
the lesser of the principal amount of the Note or the conversion
value of the Note and common stock of the Company for any
conversion value in excess of the principal amount. The Company
may redeem the Notes at its option on or after February&nbsp;15,
2011 for cash at 100% of the principal amount. Additionally, the
holders of the Notes may require the Company to purchase all or
a portion of their Notes under certain circumstances, in each
case at a repurchase price in cash equal to 100% of the
principal amount of the repurchased Notes at February&nbsp;15,
2011, February&nbsp;15, 2016, February&nbsp;15, 2021,
February&nbsp;15, 2026 and February&nbsp;15, 2031, or if certain
fundamental changes occur. The Notes are fully and
unconditionally guaranteed, on a joint and several basis, by all
of the Company&#146;s material domestic consolidated
subsidiaries. As a result of the issuance of the Notes, the
Company anticipates interest expense in fiscal 2007 to increase
approximately $6.0&nbsp;million, net of forecasted interest
income on the investment of the proceeds of the Notes. <I>See
Note&nbsp;10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
for additional information regarding the guarantors.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In connection with the issuance of the Notes, the Company
purchased a call option with respect to its common stock. If the
call option, which expires February&nbsp;15, 2011, is exercised
by the Company, it must be net share settled and in all cases
the Company would receive shares. This transaction has no effect
on the terms of the Notes, but is intended to reduce the
potential dilution upon future conversion of the Notes by
effectively increasing the initial conversion price to
$17.09&nbsp;per share, representing a 57.5% conversion premium.
The call option is exercisable under the same circumstances
which can trigger
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">27

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
conversion under the Notes. The net cost of $9.1&nbsp;million of
the purchased call option was included in shareholders&#146;
equity, along with the partially offsetting $3.4&nbsp;million
tax benefit of the call option.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
In November 2005, the Company entered into a new
$325.0&nbsp;million secured credit facility which matures in
November 2010. This facility is secured by the Company&#146;s
eligible merchandise inventory and third-party credit card
receivables. It replaced the Company&#146;s previous unsecured
bank facilities, including the three-year $125.0&nbsp;million
revolving credit facility, the $120.0&nbsp;million uncommitted
letter of credit facility, and other credit lines used for
special-purpose letters of credit. The new facility initially
bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.0% for cash borrowings. The
Company will not be required to comply with financial covenants
under the new facility unless the facility has less than
$32.5&nbsp;million available under the borrowing base as defined
in the agreement. As of February&nbsp;25, 2006, the
Company&#146;s borrowing base was $221.5&nbsp;million, of which
$127.1&nbsp;million was available for cash borrowings. The
Company pays a fee of 1.0% for standby letters of credit, 0.5%
for trade letters of credit and a commitment fee of 0.25% for
any unused amounts. The Company utilized its revolving credit
facilities for cash borrowings from August 2005 to December
2005. The greatest amount of cash borrowings outstanding on the
credit facilities at any one time was $38.5&nbsp;million. As of
February&nbsp;25, 2006, the Company had no outstanding cash
borrowings and approximately $94.5&nbsp;million in letters of
credit utilized against the new secured credit facility. Of the
outstanding balance, approximately $43.6&nbsp;million related to
trade letters of credit for merchandise purchases,
$29.0&nbsp;million related to standby letters of credit for the
Company&#146;s workers&#146; compensation and general liability
insurance policies, $19.4&nbsp;million related to standby
letters of credit for the Company&#146;s industrial revenue
bonds, and $2.4&nbsp;million related to other miscellaneous
standby letters of credit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company paid dividends totaling $34.7&nbsp;million during
fiscal 2006. Subsequent to the end of fiscal 2006, the Company
declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.10&nbsp;per share
payable on May&nbsp;17, 2006, to shareholders of record on
May&nbsp;3, 2006. The Company may continue to pay cash dividends
and repurchase its common stock in fiscal 2007, but expects to
retain most of its future earnings for support and expansion of
the Company&#146;s business. The Company&#146;s dividend policy
will depend upon the earnings, financial condition and capital
needs of the Company and other factors deemed relevant by the
Company&#146;s Board of Directors. Under the Company&#146;s new
credit facility, the Company would not be restricted from paying
dividends unless the availability under the credit facility is
less than 30% of the Company&#146;s borrowing base calculation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
During fiscal year 2006, the Company paid $4.0&nbsp;million to
repurchase&nbsp;250,000&nbsp;shares of its common stock under
the Board of Directors-approved stock buyback program at a
weighted average price of $16.19, including fees. As of
April&nbsp;24, 2006, approximately $107.4&nbsp;million remains
available for share repurchases, which may be made in open
market or private transactions from time to time depending on
prevailing market conditions, the Company&#146;s available cash,
and the Company&#146;s consideration of any loan agreement
restrictions and its corporate credit ratings. The Company paid
$6.7&nbsp;million in debt issuance costs and $9.1&nbsp;million
related to the call option purchased in conjunction with the
convertible debt offering discussed above. Other financing
activities, primarily the exercise of stock options by
employees, provided cash of $7.6&nbsp;million during fiscal 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The Company&#146;s sources of working capital for fiscal 2006
were cash flows from investing activities, bank lines of credit
and the issuance of convertible debt. The Company&#146;s secured
credit facility may limit certain investments, and in some
instances, limit the payment of dividends and repurchases of the
Company&#146;s common stock. The Company was in compliance with
all material debt covenants at fiscal 2006&nbsp;year-end. The
Company was granted a waiver by the lenders subsequent to
year-end in connection with the restatement of the
Company&#146;s consolidated statements of cash flows for fiscal
2005 and 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
From time to time, the Company purchases auction rate securities
with the intention to hold them for short periods of time and
considers them to be trading securities. Therefore, the cash
flows from the purchases and sales of these securities are
reported net in cash provided by operating activities. The
Company had no auction rate securities outstanding at either
February&nbsp;25, 2006 or February&nbsp;26, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (the &#147;Jobs
Act&#148;), enacted on October&nbsp;22, 2004, included a
provision that encourages companies to reinvest foreign earnings
in the United States by temporarily
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">28

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">
permitting certain dividends received from controlled foreign
subsidiaries to be eligible for an 85% dividends-received
deduction. Numerous requirements must be satisfied for the
repatriated earnings to qualify for the reduced rate of
taxation. The one-year period during which the Company could
make qualifying distributions was fiscal 2006. In September
2005, the Company finalized its evaluation of and the
Company&#146;s Board of Directors approved the repatriation of
$25&nbsp;million of foreign earnings under the provisions of the
Jobs Act. The Company repatriated these earnings on
September&nbsp;30, 2005 with no material impact on the
Company&#146;s effective tax rate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; ">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

other commercial commitments as of February&nbsp;25, 2006 is
listed below (in thousands):
</DIV>

    <TD colspan="9" align="left" valign="top">
    Commitments not recorded on the balance sheet</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap>1,787,278</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(1)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>

    $285.3&nbsp;million of outstanding purchase orders, which were
    primarily related to merchandise inventory. Such orders are
    generally cancelable at the discretion of the Company until the
    order has been shipped. The table above excludes certain
    immaterial executory contracts for goods and services that tend
    to be recurring in nature and similar in amount year over year
    and includes $43.6&nbsp;million in merchandise letters of credit.</TD>

    remain outstanding until maturity, the total interest paid would
    be $305.3&nbsp;million. <I>See Note&nbsp;9 of the Notes to
    Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion of the
    Company&#146;s convertible senior notes.</I></TD>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">29
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; margin-bottom: 0; color: #000000; background: #ffffff;"></DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10.0pt;color: #000000; background: #ffffff;">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(6)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>

    Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for further
    discussion of the Company&#146;s employee benefit plans.</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 3.0pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">(7)</SUP>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
